clinical_study.brief_title: The Impact of Implementing a Universal Newborn Screening for Critical Congenital Heart Disease
clinical_study.official_title: The Impact of Implementing a Universal Newborn Screening for Critical Congenital Heart Disease

lead_sponsor.agency: Mednax Center for Research, Education, Quality and Safety

clinical_study.source: Mednax Center for Research, Education, Quality and Safety

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the impact of implementing a universal pulse oximeter screening as a way to detect critical congenital heart disease in otherwise well-appearing newborns.

primary_outcome.description: The numbers of subjects who have a positive pulse oximetry screening test and who in follow-up evaluation are found to have CCHD.
The numbers of subjects who have a positive pulse oximetry screening test and who in follow-up evaluation are found to have normal hearts.
The number of subjects who have a negative pulse oximetry screening test and who in follow-up evaluation are found to have normal hearts.
The number of subjects who have a negative pulse oximetry screening test and who in follow-up evaluation are found to have heart defects.

study_pop.textblock: Neonates known to have a congenital heart defect at the time of screening.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Documentation of informed consent and authorization.
2. Full term and late preterm newborns (EGA 35-44 weeks)
3. On room air
4. Neonates known to have a congenital heart defect at the time of screening, e.g., antenatal diagnosis or diagnosis within the first 24 hours after birth
5. Parents agree to follow-up contact post discharge
Exclusion Criteria:
1. On supplemental oxygen
2. Admitted to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit
3. Parents do not agree to follow-up
4. Greater than 30 days of age
